data.event: Overall in Nebraska, not even a third of the counties saw populations increase in 2008.

event.title: ’s one more than in the previous year

data.event: That’s one more than in the previous year.
But an analysis from the University of Nebraska at Omaha’s Center for Public Affairs Research shows changes overall were better than those seen in recent years.

event.title: gained population in the one-year period after several years

data.event: Small Hitchcock and Hayes counties in southwest Nebraska, for example, both gained population in the one-year period after several years of losses.
In December, the Census bureau reported the state gained 13,959 residents over the one-year period.

event.title: ’s population (North Platte) of 35,582 is closer than ever to its all-time high set in 1981

data.event: Lincoln County’s population (North Platte) of 35,582 is closer than ever to its all-time high set in 1981.
Some counties that marked losses in 2008 saw their rates of decline slowing.

event.title: the closing of a Tyson Foods plant in 2006

data.event: Madison County, for example, lost just 20 people after losing hundreds after the closing of a Tyson Foods plant in 2006.
They now account for 52 percent of the state’s population, having more than 931,000 residents combined.
In 2000, they controlled nearly 49 percent of the state’s population.

event.title: lost about 2,700 people annually in the first six years

data.event: The district that includes more than three-fourths of the state lost about 2,700 people annually in the first six years of the decade.
But in 2008, it gained about 150 people.
Drozd estimates its total population now sits at 551,000.
In 2000, Nebraska’s slow growth sparked concern that the state could lose a seat a decade down the line.
The House lost seats in 1933, 1943 and 1963.
